questions.text: Match the following: 1. Handicapped A. Suffers from an accident and loses his body part 2. Disability B. Inability to fulfill his/her roles and responsibilities 3. Impairment C. Disease/Health Event

Impairment

  • Impairment means any loss or abnormality of physiological, psychological function, or anatomical structure.

Disability

Handicapped

  • Handicapped is when someone cannot fulfill his roles and responsibilities.

Restriction or inability to perform an activity

questions.text: A patient presents with a single painless ulcer with a clean base and indurated borders on the genitals. Which stage of syphilis does this presentation indicate, and what is the recommended medical treatment?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Primary syphilis, Benzath

Stage of Syphilis

Characteristics

Clinical Presentation

Diagnostic Features

Treatment

Primary Syphilis (Hard chancre)
  • Single painless ulcer (chancre) at the site of infection
  • Clean base and indurated (hard) borders
  • Highly infectious

  • B/L enlarged inguinal lymph nodes (Rubbery consistency)
  • Genital, anal, or oral chancre
  • Painless and may go unnoticed
  • Occurs 10-90 days after infection
  • Dark-field microscopy of exudate from chancre
  • Positive serologic tests for syphilis (e.g., VDRL, RPR)
  •  Benzathine penicillin G (IM) 2.4 million units single dose.
  • Secondary Syphilis
  • Widespread rash (maculopapular or pustular)
  • Fever, malaise, headache, sore throat
  • Lymphadenopathy (Characteristic - Epitrochlear group of lymph nodes)
  • Mucous membrane lesions
  • Moth eaten alopecia
  • Rash involving the trunk, extremities, palms, and soles
  • Generalized lymphadenopathy
  • Condylomata lata (moist, flat-topped papules) in warm, moist areas
  • Positive serologic tests for syphilis (e.g., VDRL, RPR)
  • Elevated liver enzymes, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia
  • Benzathine penicillin G (IM) 

    2.4 million units single dose

Latent Syphilis
  • Asymptomatic
  • Early latent (within 1 year of infection) or late latent (more than 1 year after infection)
  • No visible symptoms
  • Positive serologic tests for syphilis (e.g., VDRL, RPR)
  • Positive serologic tests for syphilis (e.g., VDRL, RPR)
  • Benzathine penicillin G (IM)
  • 2.4 million units single dose for early latent and 2.4 million units three doses once weekly for late latent syphilis.

Tertiary Syphilis
  • Late-stage complications affecting multiple organs
  • Gummas (soft, non-cancerous growths)
  • Cardiovascular syphilis (aortitis, aortic aneurysms)
  • Neurosyphilis (meningitis, paresis, tabes dorsalis)
  • Diverse clinical manifestations
  • Gummas in skin, bones, and internal organs
  • Neurological deficits, psychiatric symptoms
  • Aortic aneurysms, valvular insufficiencies
  • Positive serologic tests for syphilis (e.g., VDRL, RPR)
  • Cerebrospinal fluid abnormalities (if neurosyphilis suspected)
  • Benzathine penicillin G (IM) or Penicillin G (IV/IM) for neurosyphilis

Congenital Syphilis
  • Transmitted from mother to child during pregnancy
  • Various manifestations (hepatosplenomegaly, rash, bone deformities, Hutchinson teeth, saddle nose)
  • Infected infants at birth or develop symptoms within the first few months of life
  • Positive serologic tests for syphilis (e.g., VDRL, RPR) in the infant or mother
  • Benzathine penicillin G (IM) for infants and pregnant mothers

Thompson and Epstein Classification of PDH

  • Type I - Dislocation without fracture
    • No fracture
    • Pure PDH

 

  • Type II - Dislocation with a single large fracture of posterioracetabular rim
    • PDH + One chip fracture of posterior acetabular rim

 

  • Type III - Dislocation with a comminuted fracture of posterior acetabular rim
    • PDH + comminuted fracture of posterior rim

 
  • Type IV - Dislocation with fracture Acetabular floor

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to the emergency room after he s ustained a road traffic accident . His blood pressure is 88/76 mm Hg, and his pulse rate is 126 per minute . questions.explanation:
Correct Option C: Heart rate / Mean arterial pressu

Shock index

Modified shock index
  • Heart rate divided by systolic BP
  • Better marker for assessing the severity of shock than heart rate & BP alone
  • Utility in trauma patients, sepsis, obstetrics, myocardial infarction, stroke & other acute critical illnesses.
  • Correlated with the need for interventions such as blood transfusion & invasive procedure, including surgery
  • SI is known as a hemodynamic stability indicator
  • SI does not take into account the diastolic BP
  • Heart rate divided by mean arterial pressure
  • High MSI indicates a value of stroke volume & low systemic vascular resistance, a sign of hypodynamic circulation
  • Low MSI indicates a hyperdynamic state
  • MSI has been considered a better marker than SI for mortality rate prediction

questions.text: Which of the following ocular manifestations is most consistent with Vogt-Koyanagi Syndrome (VKS) based on the provided fundus photograph?

options.label: A
options.text: Retinal hemorrhages and cotton wool spots

options.label: B
options.text: Optic disc edema with macular star exudates

options.label: C
options.text: Dilated and tortuous retinal vessels with flame-shaped hemorrhages

options.label: D
options.text: Multifocal serous retinal detachments with choroidal thickening

questions.correct_answer: D. Multifocal serous retinal detachments with choroidal thickening
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Multifocal serous retinal detachments with choroidal thickening

Vogt-Koyanagi Syndrome (VKS)

Definition

Vogt-Koyanagi Syndrome (VKS) is a rare autoimmune disorder affecting multiple body systems, including the eyes, skin, and nervous system.

Eponyms

VKS is also known as Uveomeningoencephalitic Syndrome, named after ophthalmologists Alfred Vogt and Yoshizo Koyanagi.

Etiology

The exact cause of VKS is not fully understood, but it is believed to involve a combination of genetic predisposition and environmental triggers.

Clinical Features

Ocular manifestations: Bilateral uveitis (inflammation of the uvea), serous retinal detachments, choroidal thickening, and disc hyperemia.

Cutaneous manifestations: Skin depigmentation (vitiligo).

Neurological manifestations: Meningitis, headache, and other neurological deficits.

Auditory manifestations: Sensorineural hearing loss.

Stages

VKS is typically classified into four stages: prodromal, acute uveitis, chronic recurrent, and chronic recurrent convalescence.

Diagnosis

Based on clinical features and history.

Ophthalmological examination, including funduscopy, fluorescein angiography, and optical coherence tomography (OCT).

Skin examination for vitiligo.

Audiological evaluation.

Lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis to assess meningeal involvement.

Differential Diagnosis

Behçet's disease.

Sympathetic ophthalmia.

Sarcoidosis.

Tuberculosis.

Acute posterior multifocal placoid pigment epitheliopathy (APMPPE).

Treatment

Corticosteroids to suppress inflammation.

Immunosuppressive agents (e.g., azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil) for severe cases.

Biologic therapies (e.g., anti-TNF agents) for refractory cases.

Symptomatic treatment for hearing loss and neurological symptoms.

Prognosis

The prognosis varies based on disease severity and response to treatment. Early diagnosis and aggressive management can lead to better outcomes. However, some cases may experience vision loss or long-term complications.

Prevention

There is no specific way to prevent VKS, given its autoimmune nature, but early detection and appropriate treatment can help manage the disease and reduce complications.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the difference between typical and atypical antipsychotics in the treatment of schizophrenia?

options.label: A
options.text: Typical antipsychotics primarily act on positive symptoms, while atypical antipsychotics target both positive and negative symptoms.

options.label: B
options.text: Atypical antipsychotics are associated with a higher risk of extrapyramidal symptoms compared to typical antipsychotics.

options.label: C
options.text: Typical antipsychotics are more likely to cause metabolic side effects such as weight gain, hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia than atypical antipsychotics.

options.label: D
options.text: Atypical antipsychotics primarily antagonize D 2 receptors, while typical antipsychotics antagonize both D 2 and 5HT 2A receptors.

questions.correct_answer: A. Typical antipsychotics primarily act on positive symptoms, while atypical antipsychotics target both positive and negative symptoms.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A: Typical antipsychotics primarily act on positive symptoms, while atypical antipsychotics target both positive and negative symptoms.

Feature

Atypical Antipsychotics

Typical Antipsychotics (First Generation)

Primary Mechanism of Action

Block dopamine (D2) and serotonin (5HT2A) receptors.

Mainly block dopamine (D2) receptors.

Targeted Symptoms

Effective against both positive and negative symptoms.

Primarily target positive symptoms.

Risk of Extrapyramidal Symptoms

Lower risk compared to typical antipsychotics.

Higher risk, especially at higher doses.

Metabolic Side Effects

Associated with weight gain, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia.

Lower risk of metabolic side effects.

Sedation

Varies among individual medications; some can be sedating.

Tend to be more sedating.

Prolactin Elevation

Generally lower risk of causing hyperprolactinemia.

Higher risk; can lead to elevated prolactin levels.

Anticholinergic Effects

Generally lower risk of causing anticholinergic effects.

Higher risk, leading to side effects like dry mouth.

Serotonin Syndrome Risk

Lower risk due to the dual receptor antagonism.

Generally lower risk unless combined with serotonergic agents.

Examples

Clozapine, Olanzapine, Risperidone, Quetiapine, Aripiprazole

Haloperidol, Chlorpromazine, Fluphenazine, Thioridazine

questions.text: The following are various bone deformities associated with rheumatoid arthritis . Match them accordingly. 1) Swan neck deformity a) 2) Buttonhole deformity b) 3) Hitchhiker’s deformity c) 4) Z deformity d) 5) Windswept deformity e) 6) La main en lorgnette deformity f)
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - 1-c, 2-f, 3-e, 4-b, 5-a, 6

Hitchhiker’s deformity (thumb is involved).

  • Hitchhiker thumb deformity is a musculoskeletal manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis presenting in the thumb, with the combination of flexion of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint and hyperextension of the interphalangeal (IP) joint

La-Main-En-Lorgnette deformity (telescoping fingers)

  • Subluxation of PIP
  • Finger will go down and up like a telescope.

 

Boutonniere/ buttonhole deformity (proximal interphalangeal).

  • Boutonniere deformity is a deformity of the fingers in which the proximal interphalangeal joint (PIP) is flexed and the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP) is hyperextended.

Swan neck deformity (distal phalanx)

  • It is characterized by proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint hyperextension and flexion of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint.

Windswept deformity

  • One side knee joint  shows Genu valgum.
  • Other side knee joint shows Genu varum.

Z-deformity (hand)

  • Ulnar deviation of MCP with radial deviation of PIP

questions.text: A worker from Bihar has recently been hired in the aluminum industry. After returning from his hometown, he developed fever, chills, sweating, and fatigue. options.text: Eggs are round-shaped with lateral floats

questions.correct_answer: D. Eggs are round-shaped with lateral floats
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Eggs are round-shaped with lateral

Identification

  • Sits at an angle of 45°.

  • Head is downwards-resting is an inclined position.

  • Has spotted wings

Breeding

  • Anopheles breed in clean stagnant water.

  • Also called sophisticated mosquitoes.

Eggs

  • Eggs are laid singly.

  • Eggs are boat-shaped with lateral floats.

Larvae

  • Larva doesn't have a siphon tube- no breathing. Rests parallel to the surface of the water.

Flight Range

  • 2 to 3 km

questions.text: Match the following: 1 Maximum tolerated dose A Phase 1 2 Randomized control trial B Phase 2 3 Monitor rare side effects C Phase 3 4 Maximum drug failure D Phase 4
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - 1-A, 2-C, 3-D, 4-B:

Phase 0
  • Tested on Healthy Human
  • Up to 10 participants
  • Micro dosing: 1/100 of a dose because high doses may be fateful

Phase 1
  • Also tested on Healthy Human Volunteers
  • Extends from months to year (10-100)
  • Safety and Nontoxicity profile of drugs
  • Maximum tolerated dose of a drug (beyond this adverse effects of a drug occur )

Phase 2
  • Tested on Patients
  • 50-500 participants
  • Lasts for 1-2 years
  • Effectiveness and Efficacy
  • Maximum drug failure always occurs in Phase 2

Phase 3
  • Patients can be 500-3000 in number
  • This phase lasts 3-5 years
  • Comparison with existing drugs
  • Randomized Control Trial

 

Phase 4
  • Also tested on Patients
  • The study is unending till the drug removal
  • Longest phase (at least till 10-25 years)
  • Monitor Long-term and rare side effects
  • Post - marketing surveillance

Phase 1

Maximum tolerated dose

Phase 2

Maximum drug failure

Phase 3

Randomized control trial

Phase 4

Monitor rare side effects and post-marketing surveillance

questions.text: A 28-year-old nulliparous woman is undergoing evaluation for infertility. She is being monitored for ovulation with serial ultrasounds and LH levels. Ovulation is expected after how many hours of the ‘Peak’ of the ‘Upstroke’ in this diagram here:
questions.explanation:
Phase Description Duration Key Events and Hormonal Changes
Menstrual Phase (Day 1-5) Menstruation is the shedding of the uterine lining. Approximately 5 days Low levels of estrogen and progesterone. Shedding of the endometrial lining.
Follicular Phase (Day 1-13) Preparing for ovulation. Approximately 13 days Increasing levels of estrogen, which stimulate the development of ovarian follicles. FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone) plays a key role.
Ovulation (Day 14) Release of a mature egg from an ovarian follicle. A brief moment Surge in luteinizing hormone (LH) triggers ovulation. Estrogen levels peak.
Luteal Phase (Day 15-28) Post-ovulation, preparing for possible pregnancy. Approximately 14 days Progesterone levels rise, which supports the uterine lining and inhibits further ovulation. Estrogen remains elevated.

questions.text: What is the main advantage of the DIEP flap over the TRAM flap in breast reconstruction?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Lower risk of h

DIEP flap

TRAM flap
  • Deep inferior epigastric artery perforator flap
  • Muscle is not excised.
  • It contains abdominal skin, fat, and blood vessels.
  • No risk of hernia, no muscle weakness
  • Best flap for breast reconstruction
  • Transverse Rectus Abdominis Muscle flap
  • It is based on Inferior Epigastric vessels.
  • It is a type of Free flap.
  • Restore vascularity of inferior epigastric artery and vein with internal mammary artery and vein.
  • Disadvantage
    • Cutting of the abdomen causes weakness in the infra-umbilical region. This leads to an increased risk of hernia.
  • Most commonly used
  • Not the best flap

questions.text: Match the following: 1 A Pott’s puffy tumour 2 B Glomus tumour 3 C Vestibular schwannoma 4 D Chemodectoma
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - 1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-D:

1

C

Vestibular schwannoma: Showing ice cream cone appearance

 

2

A

Pott’s puffy tumor: osteomyelitis with an irregular border

3

B

Glomus tumour: Erosion of jugular spine

4

D

Chemodectoma: lyre sign

Condition

Characteristic features

Vestibular schwannoma
  • Typically benign tumor affecting the vestibular nerve.
  • It is commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type II.
  • CT and MRI reveal an enhancing mass within the internal auditory canal. 

Pott’s puffy tumour
  • Subperiosteal abscess formed secondary to the frontal bone osteomyelitis.
  • Most commonly associated with frontal sinusitis.
  • CT revels
  • Irregularity in the frontal bone
  • Subperiosteal abscess in the soft tissue of the scalp
  • Epidural abscess

Glomus tumour
  • Phelp's sign (pulsatile tinnitus synchronous with the patient's pulse) is seen
  • Glomus jugulare causes the erosion of the jugular spine.
  • The jugular foramen is destroyed.

Carotid Body Tumor (CBT)/ Chemodectoma

 
  • At the bifurcation of the common carotid artery
  • If a tumor is present, then the ICA and ECA go away. This is called the Lyre's sign.
  • CT has intense vascularity and gives salt a salt-and-pepper appearance on MRI

Acquired Nystagmus Type

Clinical Features

Associated Conditions

Ataxic Nystagmus
  • Jerky nystagmus
  • Fast phase towards the side of the lesion.

Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia (INO).

Latent Nystagmus
  • Binocular horizontal oscillation.
  • Becomes apparent when one eye is covered (cover-uncover test).

Infantile Esotropia.

Downbeat Nystagmus
  • Jerky nystagmus with a fast phase downwards.

Arnold Chiari Malformation.

Upbeat Nystagmus
  • Jerky nystagmus with a fast phase upwards.

Posterior Fossa Lesion.

Seesaw Nystagmus
  • Pendular nystagmus
  • Intorsion in the upward eye, extorsion in the downward eye.

Central Chiasmal Lesion (associated with bi-temporal hemianopia).

Convergence Retraction Nystagmus
  • Feature of Parinaud's Syndrome.

Parinaud's Syndrome.

Bruns Nystagmus
  • Feature of cerebellopontine angle tumor (acoustic neuroma).

Cerebellopontine Angle Tumor (Acoustic Neuroma).

Periodic Alternating Nystagmus (PAN)
  • Horizontal jerk on one side, changes direction periodically.

Cerebellar Lesions, Phenytoin Drug Toxicity.
